questions.questionText: What do you think happens when we unplug one of the wires from the circuit board?

rubric.exceeds: Student predicts that unplugging a wire will break the circuit and stop electricity from flowing, and explains that the electricity needs a complete path through all the wires to work.
rubric.meets: Student predicts that unplugging a wire will stop the circuit from working or turn off the light, showing understanding that all wires are needed.
rubric.approaching: Student recognizes that unplugging a wire causes something to stop working, but explanation is vague or incomplete (e.g., 'it breaks' without explaining why).
rubric.beginning: Student makes a prediction but it is inaccurate, unclear, or shows little understanding of how wires connect electricity (e.g., 'it gets fixed' or 'the wire goes away').

questions.questionText: Why do you think we need wires to connect all these parts together?

rubric.exceeds: Student explains that wires carry electricity from one part to another and that electricity needs a pathway or loop to travel through all the connected parts to make things work.
rubric.meets: Student explains that wires help electricity move between the parts or that wires connect things so they work together.
rubric.approaching: Student gives a partial explanation, such as 'wires connect things' or 'they make it work,' but does not explain the role of electricity moving through them.
rubric.beginning: Student provides a response that is unclear, off-topic, or shows minimal understanding (e.g., 'because they do' or 'to hold it together').

questions.questionText: If the light doesn't turn on, what could be wrong with our circuit?

rubric.exceeds: Student identifies multiple possible problems, such as a loose or unplugged wire, a broken wire, or the switch being in the off position, and explains how each would stop electricity from flowing.
rubric.meets: Student identifies one or two possible problems with the circuit, such as a loose wire or unplugged wire, showing understanding that a complete circuit is needed.
rubric.approaching: Student suggests one possible problem but explanation is vague or incomplete (e.g., 'the wire is broken' without explaining why this matters).
rubric.beginning: Student's response shows little understanding of circuit problems (e.g., 'it's broken' with no further explanation or an unrelated answer).

questions.questionText: Can you think of other things in your house that use circuits and electricity to work?

rubric.exceeds: Student identifies three or more household items that use electricity (such as lamps, TVs, refrigerators, or phones) and explains that they all need electricity flowing through circuits to work.
rubric.meets: Student identifies two or three household items that use electricity and recognizes they work because of circuits or electricity.
rubric.approaching: Student identifies one or two household items that use electricity, but may not clearly connect them to circuits or electricity.
rubric.beginning: Student names one item or provides a response that is unclear or unrelated to household items using electricity (e.g., 'my toy' without identifying what it does or how it works).
